Award.AwardTitle: Probing Charge Transfer Dynamics in Single QD-Molecule Complexes Using QD or Molecule Modified AFM Tips
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor Tianquan (Tim) Lian of Emory University is supported by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry (MSN) Program in the Division of Chemistry to develop a new technique for imaging charge transfer interactions in nanomaterials using integrated atomic force (AFM) and single molecule (particle) fluorescence spectroscopy. By attaching electron donors or acceptors on AFM tips, the spatial arrangement and interaction between the donor and acceptors can be controlled by AFM, while their charge transfer interaction and dynamics can be followed simultaneously using single molecule fluorescence spectroscopy. Therefore, this research is expected to offer a new and general approach for studying charge transfer interaction and dynamics in many donor-acceptor complexes, which is particularly important for nanomaterials because of the heterogeneous distributions of sizes, shapes and interactions.

The proposed study will lead to a better understanding of charge transfer processes from nanostructures (quantum dots and quantum rod) and provide guidance for the improvement of these materials and their applications in solar energy conversion technology. In addition to the training of postdoctoral fellows, graduate students and undergraduate students, the proposed research also offers the opportunity to broaden the participation of under-represented minority students through research collaborations with faculty in the Atlanta University Center, undergraduate research programs co-sponsored by the Emory Center of Science Education, and the Georgia Intern-Fellowships for Teachers (GIFT) program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

 

Cadmium chalcogenide nanoplatelets (NPLs) are a class of emerging 2-dimensional (2D) materials with potential applications in solar energy conversion and in nanoscale lasing materials. However, 2D NPLs often suffers from short exciton lifetimes, due to fast radiative and nonradiative recombination. To overcome this deficiency, we show that exciton lifetimes can be improved by the formation of type I and type II heterostructures. The property of such heterostructures depends critically on the mechanism of exciton transport in 2D materials. To this end, we have studied the mechanism of exciton transport in CdSe/CdS (type I) and CdSe/CdTe (type II) core/crown heterostructures. We showed that the crown-to-core exciton localization time increases with the crown size, consistent with diffusive transport. With excitation energy above the band edge, there is an increased contribution of hot exciton transport. The observed ultrafast and efficient hot and cold exciton crown-to-core transport suggests their potential applications as light harvesting and emitting materials.

 

Colloidal semiconductor nanocrystals have attracted intense interest as solution processable and highly tunable materials for functional lasers. To date, their performance has remained severely limited due to their small absorption cross-section and diminishing oscillator strength. To overcome these problems, we have formed an international collaboration with Prof. Volkan Demir’s team in Nanyang Technological University in Singapore to investigate lasing characteristic in 2D NPL heterostrucutres. In a paper submitted for publication, we have demonstrated efficient optical gain in Type-II nanocrystals of atomically-flat colloidal NPLs. We have achieved gain threshold as low as 26 µJ/cm2 and modal gain coefficients as high as 930 cm-1, which represent almost two-orders of magnitude enhancement over the previous best reports in Type-II nanocrystals. Our result suggests that solution-processed Type-II NPLs with efficient and tailorable gain features are expected to appeal a broad range of applications, including colloidal lasers, displays, bioimaging and medical therapeutics.

 

Colloidal lead halide perovskite quantum dots (QDs) are a new family of functional materials with potential applications in light harvesting and emitting devices. In addition, they also serve as good model system for studying bulk pervoskite materials that have shown remarkable performance in solar cells. By transient absorption spectroscopy, we showed that the high photoluminescence quantum yields can be attributed to negligible electron or hole trapping pathways in CsPbBr3 QDs. Furthermore, excitons in CsPbBr3 QDs can be efficiently dissociated in the presence of electron or hole acceptors. The lack of electron and hole traps and fast interfacial electron and hole transfer rates are key properties that may enable efficient lead halide perovskite QDs based light harvesting and emitting devices.

 

Organolead halide perovskite is one of the most promising materials for highly efficient photovoltaics. Although poor morphological control of perovskite films has been recognized as one of the key factors limiting further improvement of device efficiency, the exact origin of the morphological effect remains unclear. In collaboration with Prof. Shengye Jin’s group at Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, we carried out a study of direct mapping of carrier lifetime, intra- and inter- grain carrier diffusion coefficients, carrier diffusion length, carrier extraction efficiency with submicrometer (and subgrain) spatial resolution by photoluminescence microscopy. We observed that in high performing perovkite films, the local (intra-grain) carrier diffusivities in perovskite films are surprisingly high, similar to bulk single-crystals, and the local carrier lifetimes are long and surprisingly homogenous among perovskite grains of different sizes and shapes, and uniform across grain boundary and interior, contrary to a common belief. However, there exist large heterogeneity of carrier extraction efficiency at the perovskite grain/electrode interface and the slow inter-grain diffusion prevents the carriers from finding an alternative collection path. Our results suggest that improving inter-grain and grain/electrodes carrier transport may be promising directions for further improving the performance of perovskite thin film solar cells.

 

Broader Impact:

Our research findings in exciton dynamics and photoinduced charge transfer dynamics provide important insight into the design and improvement of materials for solar to electricity and fuel conversions. The development of a new method of imaging charge transfer dynamics with nanometer resolution adds a new tool for studying these processes. We are active participants of outreach programs that aim at broadening research participation of students at undergraduate, two-year college and high school levels. Finally, we have incorporated renewable energy research into PI’s freshman seminar class. Students in PI’s freshman seminar class presented posters at local Farmers’ Market, bringing renewable energy discussions to the general public.
